paragraphs.name: 71ff
paragraphs.text: The Living, Racist Ghosts of West Point

paragraphs.name: 59d1
paragraphs.text: Some fragile white males have taken offense to this image. (Source: New York Times)

paragraphs.name: facb
paragraphs.text: Last week, the Army launched an investigation after blogger John Burk, an Iraq veteran, posted a photograph on Facebook of sixteen black women cadets at West Point posing for their “Old Corp” photo, a time-honored tradition in which modern senior cadets mimic the old-style, black-and-white photos of cadets long past.

paragraphs.name: 0c60
paragraphs.text: Other than showing nearly every black woman in the graduating class (which, in itself, is sad and begs the question of whether the Academy should step up their “diversity outreach” efforts), nothing about it is remarkable. But Burk took issue with the “raised fist” gesture of the cadets, which he claims is meant to represent support of the #BlackLivesMatter movement. Nevermind the wealth of photographs that show white male cadets making the same gesture.

paragraphs.name: de1e
paragraphs.text: “So, let’s build a pro soccer team from scratch…”

paragraphs.name: dc67
paragraphs.text: A manifesto about startups & lower-level soccer that ends with the US winning the World Cup.

paragraphs.name: 806c
paragraphs.text: About a year ago I got hooked on this idea to start a soccer team from scratch, to put in the middle of the Hudson Valley, and try to make a run at qualifying for the US Open Cup.[1]

paragraphs.name: 3d07
paragraphs.text: [1] The US Open Cup is a 100-year-old soccer tournament that works kind-of like the NCAA basketball tourney in that lower-ranked, lower-level (even amateur) teams get the chance to compete against the biggest and best teams in all of US soccer.

paragraphs.name: 33aa
paragraphs.text: Today I accept that Rails is yesterday’s software.

paragraphs.name: 251e
paragraphs.text: I make my living, and run my entire company, on Rails, and it has been the underpinning of my career. I’ve sold every client I’ve ever had on the virtues of rapid, agile development and the insane community involvement of the Rails platform. I’ve watched DHH with ‘interest’ and admired most of the things he has to say. I’ve watched other platforms spring up to compete and enjoyed the competition between them. I stumbled across Why’s guide, I absorbed books by Pragmatic Press, watched Peepcode tutorials, Railscasts, subscribed to Codeschool, and felt a part of the industry which formed around this new style of development. Design played a bigger part not just in the websites we made, but the development tools we used. Even our API documentation appeared to breathe life.

paragraphs.name: 2be5
paragraphs.text: The Daily Routines of 15 Successful Entrepreneurs

paragraphs.name: d52a
paragraphs.text: It’s fascinating to see how some of our favorite entrepreneurs, creatives, and thought leaders spend their time every day. What are their morning routines like? What time do they rise in the morning? When are they most productive? How do they relax?

paragraphs.name: bd22
paragraphs.text: We all want to know in hopes of learning about a hidden productivity or happiness secret. So, it isn’t surprising that many of our Product Hunt LIVE guests are asked what their typical day looks like. What is surprising though, is just how different each of their answers are. Some wake up by 4am; others don’t start the day until closer to 11am. Some exercise every single day; others write or meditate. Some have their routine planned down to (what seems like) the minute; others keep more of a loose schedule.

paragraphs.name: 1b72
paragraphs.text: 40 things about life I wish I could travel back in time and tell myself

paragraphs.name: 7f1f
paragraphs.text: By John Fawkes

paragraphs.name: 79f7
paragraphs.text: Most of us have, at some point, considered what we would do if we could travel back in time. Maybe we would give ourselves some hot investment advice and become millionaires, or change history for the better, or witness our favorite historical event.

paragraphs.name: b6e7
paragraphs.text: If I could travel back in time and do one thing, I wouldn’t cheat on the stock market, or kill Hitler. I would simply give myself a few words of advice.

paragraphs.name: 0a11
paragraphs.text: https://unsplash.com/photos/EyTOnL4ST9k

paragraphs.name: fcc3
paragraphs.text: How To Quickly Learn Anything And Become More Than You Ever Thought Possible

paragraphs.name: 78cf
paragraphs.text: Dick Cheney was the 46th Vice President of the United States, and was Vice President to George W. Bush. To be sure, Cheney’s character is suspect. Many consider him to be responsible for the United States war against Iraq.

paragraphs.name: 0a80
paragraphs.text: Regardless of how you feel about Cheney, it is fascinating to consider how quickly he rose to the top of the U.S. politics.

paragraphs.name: 3cd1
paragraphs.text: After graduating from high school, Cheney began college at Yale University but shortly thereafter dropped-out due to poor grades. After a second attempt at college, he dropped out again.

paragraphs.name: 48a4
paragraphs.text: 365 ways to win or fail trying.

paragraphs.name: 1aec
paragraphs.text: How to challenge yourself to fail every day.

paragraphs.name: 1b31
paragraphs.text: I started my first business straight out of McDonald's — or as we call it here in Australia, Macca’s. I went from flipping burgers one week, waking up at 5 AM for the morning shift and driving to work in the dark, to founding a music marketing and management business.

I was a fry cook, with an anger problem and a skateboard, who threw in the apron and jumped into the world of business with a couple books on marketing and the guts to live for myself. I put my degree on hold to make it happen.

paragraphs.name: 5aa4
paragraphs.text: What should you learn to get a [better] coding job

paragraphs.name: 7f47
paragraphs.text: A lot of people ask me things like ”What should I learn to get a programming job?” or ”How can I get a job as an engineer in Silicon Valley?”

paragraphs.name: f7cf
paragraphs.text: Here’s an actual quote from last week:

paragraphs.name: f735
paragraphs.text: So, I need some advice. I am 33 years old, and I need to get out of Support and in to at least DevOps if not full-stack development, but it’s so expensive. Any advice on what I should learn first?

paragraphs.name: 540f
paragraphs.text: The implication is usually which technology should you learn to get a job. As if your choice of technology is some kind of silver bullet.

paragraphs.name: f007
paragraphs.text: Thank you @breather on Unsplash.com

paragraphs.name: 2be1
paragraphs.text: Tiny startups need tiny boards

paragraphs.name: fd70
paragraphs.text: I got a call from a brilliant young French entrepreneur the other day asking me about composing the board for his startup as he was closing his seed round. It seemed like every angel writing a check wanted to be on the board as well as some notable industry players. Here is what I told him: resist the pressure!

paragraphs.name: 3c21
paragraphs.text: Optimize for speed

paragraphs.name: e81f
paragraphs.text: As an early stage startup, speed is probably your core KPI. Of course you need to carefully consider your strategy given that you’re acting with limited resources, but the reality is that you’re having to make important decisions ALL the time. Recruitment, product, pricing, fundraising, co-founder issues, you name it.

paragraphs.name: e62d
paragraphs.text: I Can’t Tell You Why Our Business Is Growing

paragraphs.name: 2cf0
paragraphs.text: Unsplash photo

paragraphs.name: ed42
paragraphs.text: On my way to the co-working space, I grabbed my mobile to read the same Slack message yet another time:

paragraphs.name: d2fe
paragraphs.text: “Ali, that’s good, but we should look at what converts.”

paragraphs.name: 7dd9
paragraphs.text: It never failed. It was either a client or a colleague on the same marketing team. There was always someone who never missed the perfect opportunity to remind me of the importance of a conversion funnel:

paragraphs.name: 68cf
paragraphs.text: Get a bunch of website visitors,

paragraphs.name: a899
paragraphs.text: then do something to turn some of them into leads — aka people who have shown interest in your business,

paragraphs.name: 89d5
paragraphs.text: My Advice for First-Time Entrepreneurs

paragraphs.name: f98a
paragraphs.text: I’ve said it time and time again: Entrepreneurship is hard and it’s not for everyone. If, after taking a realistic personal inventory of who you are and what you want to be doing, it turns out that you are ready to take the next steps in starting a business, I want to discuss the advice I always give to first-time entrepreneurs.

paragraphs.name: 350f
paragraphs.text: 1. Be Practical About Your Money

paragraphs.name: 6ea0
paragraphs.text: The first and most important thing that I tell new entrepreneurs is the importance of practicality when it comes to to money. I’m blown away by all the “entrepreneurs” who start businesses and at launch, don’t realize the importance of generating money and how to manage profits. Instead of focusing on the present financial needs and building an actual company, they are too busy thinking about how much money they’ll be making four years from now. It’s a complete lack of practicality.

paragraphs.name: b388
paragraphs.text: Why I Scrapped My Big Career for The Long Journey

paragraphs.name: 61f1
paragraphs.text: Fresh coconut, Yoga Barn, Ubud, Bali.

paragraphs.name: e5d6
paragraphs.text: At 25 I landed my dream job as a graphic designer at Pixar.

paragraphs.name: 2b58
paragraphs.text: Freaking Pixar.

paragraphs.name: d140
paragraphs.text: Holding that offer letter was like having the world at my fingertips, but by then my hands were burning with so much pain I could hardly move them.

paragraphs.name: 11d5
paragraphs.text: A decade before — when I was 15 and greener than the Appalachians in the summertime — the term “dream job” meant I got extra tips for putting up with lewd comments from old men while clearing away their dishes.

paragraphs.name: c207
paragraphs.text: What is the purpose of a logo? It’s more than design…it’s about purpose

paragraphs.name: 8fe6
paragraphs.text: My friend Spencer Chen, VP of marketing and business development for Alibaba, blew up Twitter recently by observing that many hot tech companies have apparently borrowed their logos from previous designs. While there is a finite set of possibilities specifically for logos based on a single character, the resemblances are striking and uncanny nonetheless. Furthermore, the logos of Airbnb, Beats, Flipboard and Medium all seem to be based on designs featured in a 1989 design book, “Trademarks & Symbols of the World: The Alphabet in Design.”

paragraphs.name: e275
paragraphs.text: Six books that explain the world of today

paragraphs.name: 3b48
paragraphs.text: As technology is eating the world everything is becoming increasingly complicated. One could say that we are in troubled waters. Or that we know nothing.

paragraphs.name: ca10
paragraphs.text: That’s good news for explorers.

paragraphs.name: 8fe5
paragraphs.text: And for people who like to read. We do. If you do too, these six books will give you a comprehensive understanding of the world as it is now and where it is heading.

A lot of books published recently are circling the same themes and topics with small variations — technology and its influence on both big and small in the world of today. But the level of quality and argument is very different.

paragraphs.name: 1a25
paragraphs.text: Choice: The New Democracy of Music

paragraphs.name: 8b5e
paragraphs.text: Credit: Freestocks — https://stocksnap.io/author/20064

paragraphs.name: d678
paragraphs.text: Long before “Netflix & Chill” was synonymous with sloppy Tinder finger-banging on a loveseat gifted from a family friend, Netflix was actually a different frontier altogether. Netflix is a symbol of unified consumer choice for a fee. In fact, Netflix has proven to be the great unity point of movie and TV consumers across the planet; if you’re not paying for Netflix, you’re probably stealing someone else’s password. (*Coughing loudly in the general direction of my younger sister.*)

paragraphs.name: 8a66
paragraphs.text: Why Uber and Lyft left Austin

paragraphs.name: 6eec
paragraphs.text: Right now, as a resident in Austin, Texas, I am unable to call an Uber or Lyft. As of 8 am today, both companies have left the city of Austin with no public intention of ever coming back. The reason why the ridesharing companies left was because Proposition 1, a proposition that required a special election for the city of Austin on May 7th, failed. The Daily Dot has had fantastic coverage on the issue, and summarizes it as follows:

paragraphs.name: ab97
paragraphs.text: UI Interactions of the week #24
via Muzli design inspiration

paragraphs.text: 昼研社 by 灰昼

paragraphs.text: Antivirus software by RF_Phil

paragraphs.text: iOS App Onboarding Flow by Ramotion

paragraphs.name: aac3
paragraphs.text: Slide by Lewis

paragraphs.name: 598f
paragraphs.text: 11 Signs You Should NOT Work For A Startup

paragraphs.name: cea1
paragraphs.text: Source: Pexels.com

paragraphs.name: ff4e
paragraphs.text: Having been ‘born into’ a start-up in my professional life, graduating and going straight into The Culture Trip, I’ve spent the last few years thinking about what it means to work in this type of company. Importantly, I’ve seen a number of people come and go, lured into the start-up world by all the wrong factors, only to find themselves completely unsuitable, and ultimately unhappy. As a new generation graduates this summer, I want to tell you the truth of working in a start-up: all about the blood and sweat and tears, the real demands, the uncertainty of it all. I want you to think long and hard before you even send your CV to a founder, wasting his and your time. But if it turns out that by the end of this article, you’re still excited by our amazing, challenging, trailblazing world, then welcome to the club, start-up kid.

paragraphs.name: 8a16
paragraphs.text: (image via Bill Bradshaw)

paragraphs.name: aba1
paragraphs.text: The Falling Apple

paragraphs.name: 199e
paragraphs.text: Wall Street wants Apple to be Amazon. Not happening.

paragraphs.name: edce
paragraphs.text: If Apple hasn’t hit peak iPhone yet, they now appear pretty close to it. Sure, the iPhone 7 will likely kick things up a notch once again, but it will probably be a smaller notch than before. The era of hyper-growth seems over. Quite the “problem” to have: Apple has conquered the high-end smartphone market and created what is perhaps the greatest business this world has ever known as a result.

paragraphs.name: c824
paragraphs.text: Wall Street, naturally, is panicking. Because if you’re not busy growing, you’re busy dying. This is ridiculous, of course. But that’s today’s Wall Street, where profits are just the unfortunate residue of a lack of commitment to growth. Everyone is buying the future, not the present. Dividends are for the unimaginative.

paragraphs.name: bd24
paragraphs.text: You’re the mom now, dog.
Mother and child (and standard-sized bouquet in her book)

paragraphs.name: 99ea
paragraphs.text: Some pro tips for dealing with dementia and his inbred cousin, Alzheimer’s

paragraphs.name: e808
paragraphs.text: My earliest memory of my mom is from an Easter Sunday when I was a toddler. I don’t know the year and have no photo of the moment, but I can picture the oversized mylar bunny balloon and our color-coordinated outfits clearly. We didn’t go to church that day. Nothing spectacular happened. And yet these images have stuck with me. This is my earliest recollection of how Mom made every occasion — Christian and otherwise — a religious experience. From the resurrection to a first day at any new job, everything and anything is worth celebrating in Mom’s eyes. She transforms unremarkable moments into Hallmark holidays. If you don’t believe me, just ask to see the valentines she sent my dog this year.

virtuals.emailSnippet:
I got a call from a brilliant young French entrepreneur the other day asking me about composing the board for his startup as he was closing his seed round. It seemed like every angel writing a check wanted to be on the board as well as some notable industry players. Here is what I told him: resist the pressure! ¶

Optimize for speed ¶

As an early stage startup, speed is probably your core KPI. Of course you need to carefully consider your strategy given that you’re acting with limited…

paragraphs.name: previewTitle
paragraphs.text: Tiny startups need tiny boards

paragraphs.name: previewSubtitle
paragraphs.text: Complexity kills and speed matters. At seed : keep your board tight !

9367e461a46f.title: I Can’t Tell You Why Our Business Is Growing

content.subtitle: On my way to the co-working space, I grabbed my mobile to read the same Slack message yet another time:

virtuals.snippet: On my way to the co-working space, I grabbed my mobile to read the same Slack message yet another time:
virtuals.subtitle: On my way to the co-working space, I grabbed my mobile to read the same Slack message yet another time:
virtuals.emailSnippet:
“Ali, that’s good, but we should look at what converts.” ¶

It never failed. It was either a client or a colleague on the same marketing team. There was always someone who never missed the perfect opportunity to remind me of the importance of a conversion funnel: ¶

Get a bunch of website visitors, ¶

then do something to turn some of them into leads — aka people who have shown interest in your business, ¶

and then do something else to turn those leads into customers.

paragraphs.name: e62d
paragraphs.text: I Can’t Tell You Why Our Business Is Growing

virtuals.emailSnippet:
who you are and what you want to be doing, it turns out that you are ready to take the next steps in starting a business, I want to discuss the advice I always give to first-time entrepreneurs. ¶

1. Be Practical About Your Money ¶

The first and most important thing that I tell new entrepreneurs is the importance of practicality when it comes to to money. I’m blown away by all the “entrepreneurs” who start businesses and at launch, don’t realize the importance of generating money and how to…

34ad670eecd9.title: Why I Scrapped My Big Career for The Long Journey

content.subtitle: At 25 I landed my dream job as a graphic designer at Pixar.

virtuals.snippet: At 25 I landed my dream job as a graphic designer at Pixar.
virtuals.subtitle: At 25 I landed my dream job as a graphic designer at Pixar.
virtuals.emailSnippet:
Freaking Pixar. ¶

Holding that offer letter was like having the world at my fingertips, but by then my hands were burning with so much pain I could hardly move them. ¶

A decade before — when I was 15 and greener than the Appalachians in the summertime — the term “dream job” meant I got extra tips for putting up with lewd comments from old men while clearing away their dishes. ¶

I had come a long way.

c7dfdc783d1e.title: What is the purpose of a logo? It’s more than design…it’s about purpose

content.subtitle: My friend Spencer Chen, VP of marketing and business development for Alibaba, blew up Twitter recently by observing that many hot tech…

virtuals.snippet: My friend Spencer Chen, VP of marketing and business development for Alibaba, blew up Twitter recently by observing that many hot tech…
virtuals.subtitle: My friend Spencer Chen, VP of marketing and business development for Alibaba, blew up Twitter recently by observing that many hot tech…
virtuals.emailSnippet: companies have apparently borrowed their logos from previous designs. While there is a finite set of possibilities specifically for logos based on a single character, the resemblances are striking and uncanny nonetheless. Furthermore, the logos of Airbnb, Beats, Flipboard and Medium all seem to be based on designs featured in a 1989 design book, “Trademarks & Symbols of the World: The Alphabet in Design.”

8f5aaa237978.title: Six books that explain the world of today

content.subtitle: As technology is eating the world everything is becoming increasingly complicated. One could say that we are in troubled waters. Or that we…

virtuals.snippet: As technology is eating the world everything is becoming increasingly complicated.
virtuals.subtitle: As technology is eating the world everything is becoming increasingly complicated. One could say that we are in troubled waters. Or that we…
virtuals.emailSnippet:
know nothing. ¶

That’s good news for explorers. ¶

And for people who like to read. We do. If you do too, these six books will give you a comprehensive understanding of the world as it is now and where it is heading. ¶

A lot of books published recently are circling the same themes and topics with small variations — technology and its influence on both big and small in the world of today. But the level of quality and argument is very different.

c2b9fa83f72e.title: Choice: The New Democracy of Music

content.subtitle: Long before “Netflix & Chill” was synonymous with sloppy Tinder finger-banging on a loveseat gifted from a family friend, Netflix was…

virtuals.snippet: Long before “Netflix & Chill” was synonymous with sloppy Tinder finger-banging on a loveseat gifted from a family friend, Netflix was…
virtuals.subtitle: Long before “Netflix & Chill” was synonymous with sloppy Tinder finger-banging on a loveseat gifted from a family friend, Netflix was…
virtuals.emailSnippet:
actually a different frontier altogether. Netflix is a symbol of unified consumer choice for a fee. In fact, Netflix has proven to be the great unity point of movie and TV consumers across the planet; if you’re not paying for Netflix, you’re probably stealing someone else’s password. (*Coughing loudly in the general direction of my younger sister.*) ¶

Consumers want access and convenience, and streaming movie/TV services like Netflix have demonstrated this beautifully.

5f79fb095aad.title: Why Uber and Lyft left Austin

content.subtitle: Right now, as a resident in Austin, Texas, I am unable to call an Uber or Lyft. As of 8 am today, both companies have left the city of…

virtuals.snippet: Right now, as a resident in Austin, Texas, I am unable to call an Uber or Lyft. As of 8 am today, both companies have left the city of…
virtuals.subtitle: Right now, as a resident in Austin, Texas, I am unable to call an Uber or Lyft. As of 8 am today, both companies have left the city of…
virtuals.emailSnippet:
Austin with no public intention of ever coming back. The reason why the ridesharing companies left was because Proposition 1, a proposition that required a special election for the city of Austin on May 7th, failed. The Daily Dot has had fantastic coverage on the issue, and summarizes it as follows: ¶

Prop. 1 would have replaced an ordinance adopted in December that required TNCs to conduct fingerprint-based background checks.

ba53330e857a.title: 11 Signs You Should NOT Work For A Startup

content.subtitle: Having been ‘born into’ a start-up in my professional life, graduating and going straight into The Culture Trip, I’ve spent the last few…

virtuals.snippet: Having been ‘born into’ a start-up in my professional life, graduating and going straight into The Culture Trip, I’ve spent the last few…
virtuals.subtitle: Having been ‘born into’ a start-up in my professional life, graduating and going straight into The Culture Trip, I’ve spent the last few…
virtuals.emailSnippet: years thinking about what it means to work in this type of company. Importantly, I’ve seen a number of people come and go, lured into the start-up world by all the wrong factors, only to find themselves completely unsuitable, and ultimately unhappy. As a new generation graduates this summer, I want to tell you the truth of working in a start-up: all about the blood and sweat and tears, the real demands, the uncertainty of it all.

content.subtitle: Wall Street wants Apple to be Amazon. Not happening.

virtuals.snippet: Wall Street wants Apple to be Amazon. Not happening.
virtuals.subtitle: Wall Street wants Apple to be Amazon. Not happening.
virtuals.emailSnippet:
If Apple hasn’t hit peak iPhone yet, they now appear pretty close to it. Sure, the iPhone 7 will likely kick things up a notch once again, but it will probably be a smaller notch than before. The era of hyper-growth seems over. Quite the “problem” to have: Apple has conquered the high-end smartphone market and created what is perhaps the greatest business this world has ever known as a result. ¶

Wall Street, naturally, is panicking.

paragraphs.name: aba1
paragraphs.text: The Falling Apple

paragraphs.name: 199e
paragraphs.text: Wall Street wants Apple to be Amazon. Not happening.

content.subtitle: Some pro tips for dealing with dementia and his inbred cousin, Alzheimer’s

virtuals.snippet: Some pro tips for dealing with dementia and his inbred cousin, Alzheimer’s
virtuals.subtitle: Some pro tips for dealing with dementia and his inbred cousin, Alzheimer’s
virtuals.emailSnippet: My earliest memory of my mom is from an Easter Sunday when I was a toddler. I don’t know the year and have no photo of the moment, but I can picture the oversized mylar bunny balloon and our color-coordinated outfits clearly. We didn’t go to church that day. Nothing spectacular happened. And yet these images have stuck with me. This is my earliest recollection of how Mom made every occasion — Christian and otherwise — a religious experience.

paragraphs.name: bd24
paragraphs.text: You’re the mom now, dog.

paragraphs.name: 99ea
paragraphs.text: Some pro tips for dealing with dementia and his inbred cousin, Alzheimer’s
